Thanks!
maintainer merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

I wonder what's your consideration for including all smaller `k` rather than just what's necessary, for example
```suggestion
    (odd : âˆ€ m : â„•, P (m + 1) â†’ P (m + 2) â†’ P (m + 3) â†’ P (m + 4) â†’ P (2 * (m + 2) + 1)) (n : â„•) : P n :=
```
in this case? Seems like this would save you some `linarith` when applying it.
Another comment: since this is Sort-valued, you could even define `preNormEDS'` using this, or directly define `preNormEDS` using `normEDSRec` below.
I will change the assumptions. I was told that defining `preNormEDS` using the equation compiler is more elegant.
Yeah I already changed the `even` `odd` assumptions as indicated above in #13057; it's only used once though. I agree it's probably fine to leave the definition of `preNormEDS'` as is.

Actually after thinking about it for a bit maybe including all smaller `k` might make it more convenient for me in #10878? In line 464 of the `DivisionPolynomial` file I did something fancy: I replaced the inductive hypotheses with something in terms of `natDegree` and `coeff`, but the same chunk of code somehow worked in the even and odd case simultaneously! If I used your version I feel like the code would be twice longer.
We can certainly have both versions if that's the case :)
The `natAbs` is unnecessary here and I removed it in #13057. (I also corrected some capitalization like `IsEllSequence_id` there.)
Note that I renamed these to `.smul` instead of changing the capitalization, enabling dot notation.

I think we are missing the recursion principle assuming `(nonneg : âˆ€ n : â„•, P n) (neg : âˆ€ n : â„•, P n â†’ P (-n))`, and `normEDS` is simply the combination of this principle with `normEDS'`. This is usually achieved with `wlog : 0 â‰¤ n` in my PR, but it requires deducing `0 â‰¤ -n` from `Â¬ n â‰¤ 0`, which is annoying whether you use `linarith` or explicit lemmas like I do.

If we add this then `normEDSRec` can be removed, and the name can be used by the version I suggested, or maybe a more general version where the inductive hypotheses are like `even : âˆ€ m : â„•, (âˆ€ k : â„¤, 0 â‰¤ k â†’ k < 2 * (m + 3), P k) â†’ P (2 * (m + 3))`, which would avoid rewrites before applying the inductive hypotheses.
Well we do have `Int.rec` that recurses on `ofNat` and `negSucc`... do you think we still want this and call it something like `Int.rec'`?

Yes it would be more convenient. We want to use the ofNat case in the negSucc case, without first stating the ofNat case (we want to create it automatically as a goal). Maybe the name could be negRec or nonnegNegRec.

I'm still not super convinced that we need both `normEDSRec` and `normEDSRec'`, but I've repurposed it as you said and added `Int.negInduction`. I'm somewhat disgusted by the naming inconsistency with the other recursion/induction defs in that file, so someone has to fix those in a separate PR eventually.

I think putting the base cases in one line is prettier:
```suggestion
noncomputable def normEDSRec {P : â„• â†’ Sort u}
    (base0 : P 0) (base1 : P 1) (base2 : P 2) (base3 : P 3) (base4 : P 4)
```
This is a bit different from my version (you assume a Nat-indexed rather than Int-indexed sequence, so you can't have `P (m - 2)` etc.) but I think I can adapt.

Why do you change parentheses to `<|`? It's one character longer and to me it doesn't look as nice. I'd use `<|` only to avoid nested parentheses.
```suggestion
lemma IsEllDivSequence.smul (h : IsEllDivSequence W) (x : R) : IsEllDivSequence (x â€¢ W) :=
  âŸ¨h.left.smul W x, h.right.smul W xâŸ©
```
It's a habit of mine, and I do think mine looks nicer :)

Can you elaborate? In paper mathematics, function application is usually written `f(x)` with parentheses, so I'd argue mine is closer to the common mathematics notation. When there are nested parentheses people may use different kinds of delimiters like {}, [] at different levels in addition to (), which are not available in Lean, so `<|` is a nice workaround in this regard.

```suggestion
variable {W}

lemma IsEllSequence.smul (h : IsEllSequence W) (x : R) : IsEllSequence <| x â€¢ W :=
```
[Polynomial.Chebyshev.induct](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/RingTheory/Polynomial/Chebyshev.html#Polynomial.Chebyshev.induct) is like a toy version of this :)
